commit_message:
Enhance StackResource update for more use cases

Enhance StackResource.update_with_template to accommodate more
possible use cases. This will take care of the nested stack update
failure by raising an exception in such case, so the the concrete
nested stack resource implementations will have a chance to take
some actions upon nested stack update failure.

blueprint nested-stack-updates

Change-Id: Id31ef67e1d7c4928704c6e169bce13f0f7232932

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-09 04:31:47.000000000', 'message': "No relevant message when stop a stopped VM

When user tries to stop a stopped VM, there is no need to stop it again,
and We need return it's vm_state.

Fixes bug 1181934

Change-Id: I71772dfcead440cb49b6ccdbb4e1a891475bb75e
(cherry picked from commit 62ca3783ce4fcc0b03e96936972abc83b54c772f)
"}]
commit_message:
No relevant message when stop a stopped VM

When user tries to stop a stopped VM, there is no need to stop it again,
and We need return it's vm_state.

Fixes bug 1181934

Change-Id: I71772dfcead440cb49b6ccdbb4e1a891475bb75e
(cherry picked from commit 62ca3783ce4fcc0b03e96936972abc83b54c772f)

commit_message:
Move sqlachemy tests only in test_impl_sqlachemy

Some tests test the ceilometer storage model convertion to the
sqlachemy database model add must be in the test_impl_sqlachemy and not
in the base file.

This change is needs by the blueprint db-tests-with-scenarios

Change-Id: I057079fc27ef8b9a0a379f4d266d1fd3a8ce2671

commit_message:
Raise Error when pagination/groupby is missing

Raise NotImplementedError if db2 storage backend doesn't
support the pagination or the groupby API.

This change is needs by the blueprint db-tests-with-scenarios

Change-Id: I7dfeab96e30ae6640f969bb76da9a41045922a64

commit_message:
Ignore stmf target must be offline exception

Patch to ignore

"NexentaJSONException: : Unable to add member to targetgroup:
  stmfadm: STMF target must be offline"

This error happens when targetgroup is already configured and busy.

fixed bug 1209305

Change-Id: I2441118c0968a7a373b5990db6782129291c3051

[{'created': '2013-08-12 15:34:01.000000000', 'message': 'Fix simultaneous timeout with smart iptables usage

This was due to our inefficient use of iptables where we attempt

plug, and restart_dhcp.

This patch makes the iptables code a little bit smarter by only

a small difference in the interpretation of duplicate rules.
Previously, the last copy of the rule would win whereas now

commit_message:
Fix simultaneous timeout with smart iptables usage

Simultaneous boots were getting timeouts in allocate_for_network.
This was due to our inefficient use of iptables where we attempt
to recreate the same rules over and over using initialize_gateway,
plug, and restart_dhcp.

This patch makes the iptables code a little bit smarter by only
shelling out if the rule list has changed. Note that there is
a small difference in the interpretation of duplicate rules.
Previously, the last copy of the rule would win whereas now
the first copy of the rule will win. Multiple copies of the same
rule were never supported. This means the only thing that one
needs to remember is it is necessary to remove a rule and re-add
it if you want to move it later in the list.

Fixes bug 1199433

Change-Id: I9920f8d6aa269d9b3bfd88a8dbbb00f859deb158
(cherry picked from commit 176c483cdf2bc8eff7cfff4a9b0ac0dd98239da1)

commit_message:
Add support for source security groups

This patch adds support for the SourceSecurityGroupName and
SourceSecurityGroupId properties. It covers Nova and Neutron.

Change-Id: Ic12512dfb4375ccccbe1282bb48b80cde16ceb9d
Fixes: bug #1193415

commit_message:
Raise Error when pagination support is missing

Raise NotImplementedError if storage backend doesn't support the
pagination.

This change is needs by the blueprint db-tests-with-scenarios

Change-Id: I1c234697cf4522167dd5b22107028ddd0f40a4c7

commit_message:
Added ability to specify services location

Changed how list of services is sorting. Now it sorted by service name, not file name.
Change-Id: I6c48f803b57399604211ad9a9faee44d87d4dd6d

commit_message:
Clean up keystone-manage man page

Several warnings were generated from keystone-manage when
building docs. Also, the options without a description
didn't display correctly in the rendered result.

Also, I added a description for the new db_version subcommand.

To generate the new option list, I ran keystone-manage --help
and copy-pasted the options into the doc.

Change-Id: I1a405ca03d894c9c3e0f6b3bfccc9bcfcce1302d

'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-08-18 01:38:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

We've had a long chat about this. I understand now that we don't need a continual stream of these, we can just merge them when we actually need a changed requirement, and before releases so that pypi versions are fresh.

That said, we don't need these changes yet, so I'm marking this do-not-merge until we do (or we're about to release)."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-08-18 01:38:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Concerns noted - and you don't have to merge these all the time. However, you're participating in the mirror now, and you're going to be subject to requirements gating - so I'd like to get you aligned to the current state of the world now that you're in the openstack repo-group. Also, I'd like to get rid of your depend on d2to1, because we're trying to eradicate it across the board."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-18 04:03:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-10 21:19:04.000000000', 'message': 'Fix ratelimiting

Current master does not respect ratelimiting, since parsing of the
api-paste.ini is faulty. api-paste.ini limited user limiting by
setting a line as follows:
user:<user-id>:(GET, *, ".*", 4, minute)

This was passed to the Limiter as kwargs with "user" as a key.
Thus multiple user limiting is not possible as well as extracting
the id of the user was bound to fail, since we checked on the key
with startswith("user:")

An example config in the api-paste.ini has to look as follows:
limits = (POST, "*", .*, 10, MINUTE)
limits.<user-id1>:(GET, "*", .*, 4, minute)
limits.<user-id2>:(GET, "*", .*, 2, minute)

The code has been modified to be able to handle such configs

Fixes bug: 1210869

Change-Id: Iaec669b282a567d42fbe21a6f64e7bc99161053b

commit_message:
Fix ratelimiting

Current master does not respect ratelimiting, since parsing of the
api-paste.ini is faulty. api-paste.ini limited user limiting by
setting a line as follows:
user:<user-id>:(GET, *, ".*", 4, minute)

This was passed to the Limiter as kwargs with "user" as a key.
Thus multiple user limiting is not possible as well as extracting
the id of the user was bound to fail, since we checked on the key
with startswith("user:")

An example config in the api-paste.ini has to look as follows:
limits = (POST, "*", .*, 10, MINUTE)
limits.<user-id1>:(GET, "*", .*, 4, minute)
limits.<user-id2>:(GET, "*", .*, 2, minute)

The code has been modified to be able to handle such configs

Fixes bug: 1210869

Change-Id: Iaec669b282a567d42fbe21a6f64e7bc99161053b

commit_message:
VMware: Added check for datastore state before selection

The driver only checked for the datastore type. The datastore could
be in an inaccessible state. In such cases creating an instance to
such datastore will fail. The fix to filter out inaccessible data-
stores.

The datastores have a property called accessible. The fix is to use
this property to filter out inaccessible datastores.

fix bug #1194078

Change-Id: I372fc3adc0e89c48d86f1f70164263ed35184c5d

commit_message:
Move the frequently injection task to the base folder.

Key/value injection is a typical way to bootstrap a
dependency based system (as there needs to be an
initial set of values to depend on). Since this inject
task is frequently used to accomplish this we should
just move it to the base file.

Change-Id: Ib49e949f319bc18744fc95f8a02fab1eade0fb6a

[{'created': '2013-08-25 11:51:50.000000000', 'message': 'Remove explicit version from setup.cfg

With the explicit "pre version" in setup.cfg, PBR generates our
version as 1.2.0.a1.g2748574 and, without it, it generates
1.2.0a4.1.g2748574.

which in turn causes nova to complain about:

 VersionConflict: (oslo.config 1.2.0.a1.g2748574
 (/opt/stack/new/oslo.config),
 Requirement.parse('oslo.config>=1.2.0a3'))

when trying to load extensions with stevedore.

I'm not sure why this is suddenly an issue after 1.2.0a4 has been
tagged, but removing this version is the right thing to do anyway
since we want to rely on tags for all versioning info.

Change-Id: I9090b8401a43befd73a82f9bb78e0b6165619c7c
'}]
commit_message:
Remove explicit version from setup.cfg

With the explicit "pre version" in setup.cfg, PBR generates our
version as 1.2.0.a1.g2748574 and, without it, it generates
1.2.0a4.1.g2748574.

which in turn causes nova to complain about:

 VersionConflict: (oslo.config 1.2.0.a1.g2748574
 (/opt/stack/new/oslo.config),
 Requirement.parse('oslo.config>=1.2.0a3'))

when trying to load extensions with stevedore.

I'm not sure why this is suddenly an issue after 1.2.0a4 has been
tagged, but removing this version is the right thing to do anyway
since we want to rely on tags for all versioning info.

Change-Id: I9090b8401a43befd73a82f9bb78e0b6165619c7c

commit_message:
Document CONF.default_flavor is for EC2 only

CONF.default_flavor is only used in the EC2 API, so update the help
message to reflect that.

Partial-Bug: #1207553

Change-Id: I3f263c564b619a32a69f5170ab07eddfba77f60b

commit_message:
Upgrade to Hacking 0.7

There was a bug in hacking 0.6 that broke H202, assertRaises Exception
too broad, so switch to Hacking 0.7 and fix the one H202 bug.

Change-Id: Ia3fb22d1524022479d7068cb84a3bdf7ca19f408

'}, {'created': '2013-08-08 06:31:44.000000000', 'message': "VMware: fix rescue/unrescue instance

Fixes bug 1199955

The problem is due to the way in which the VM's are named on vCenter.
That is, in Nova a VM has a name and a UUID. In vCenter the VM only
has a name. The VM name on vCenter is Nova's instance UUID. When the
rescue/unrescue operation takes place a new VM is spawned/destroyed.
The Nova VM has the name '<name>-rescue'. The problem is that the
new rescue name was not passed correctly to the vCenter, that is,
it should have been '<uuid>-rescue' but it was just '<uuid>'. This
caused the opertaion to fail as there is already a VM with that name

Change-Id: Icfe6e5021b29026788bec8f3526f94a8ec0a65e2

commit_message:
VMware: fix rescue/unrescue instance

Fixes bug 1199955

The problem is due to the way in which the VM's are named on vCenter.
That is, in Nova a VM has a name and a UUID. In vCenter the VM only
has a name. The VM name on vCenter is Nova's instance UUID. When the
rescue/unrescue operation takes place a new VM is spawned/destroyed.
The Nova VM has the name '<name>-rescue'. The problem is that the
new rescue name was not passed correctly to the vCenter, that is,
it should have been '<uuid>-rescue' but it was just '<uuid>'. This
caused the opertaion to fail as there is already a VM with that name
on vCenter. A new name should have been passed which is '<uuid>-rescue'.

Change-Id: Icfe6e5021b29026788bec8f3526f94a8ec0a65e2

(1 inline comment)

I would like to see more explanation of the problem and the fix in the commit message so people don't have to have access to Launchpad to understand it.

Also, I'm wondering if this is the right place to make the fix.  It seems like the quota processing code should be smart enough to handle this situation.  I feel like maybe it would be better to fix the logic bug that was allowing this than to just make sure we're setting all of the user quotas."}, {'account_id': 4428, 'date': '2013-08-12 00:26:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-12 00:30:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

I left a comment inline with a suggestion.  Let me know what you think.'}, {'account_id': 4428, 'date': '2013-08-12 15:43:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Hi, Ben

Thanks for the comment, reply inline'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-08-13 01:58:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Okay, I misread the bug originally.  I see that the issue is not that the quota isn't being enforced (it looks to me like it still would be, even if the user quota is set higher than the project quota), it's just that the user quota shouldn't be able to get set higher than the project quota.

Digging a little deeper, I see that a similar change already went in to Nova, and Nova doesn't actually appear to use the Oslo quota code.  So, I think now I'd like to see a test case for Oslo that demonstrates the bug is present here too.  I wouldn't be surprised if it is, but since this code isn't shared with Nova we can't assume the bug is shared either, and we should have a test case for this behavior anyway since it obviously could be problematic.

Sorry for the earlier confusion on my end.  Hopefully this makes more sense. :-)"}, {'account_id': 4428, 'date': '2013-08-13 03:38:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-13 03:43:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
User quota update should not exceed project quota

When user quota is not set, the default quota set in
config file will be used as the default user quota,
this will break the logic of user quota (the default
user quota should be restricted by the project quota)

Fixes bug 1208400
Fixes bug 1205582

Change-Id: Id98d504d8f5e0dda642fa5e7c550acea79520c3d

commit_message:
fileutils: don't import __builtin__

This doesn't exists in Python 3, so let's just use six for this.

Change-Id: I9634179372351c912d5d8c200676e405aabbed59

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-23 12:40:56.000000000', 'message': 'Only create user_creds row on initial stack store

We should only store the credentials on inital stack store,
otherwise we end up creating orphan user_creds rows every
time the stack status is updated.

Fixes bug #1197074

Change-Id: Ib8414dd774386578dbc4d654b1773727d2998f80
'}]
commit_message:
Only create user_creds row on initial stack store

We should only store the credentials on inital stack store,
otherwise we end up creating orphan user_creds rows every
time the stack status is updated.

Fixes bug #1197074

Change-Id: Ib8414dd774386578dbc4d654b1773727d2998f80

commit_message:
remove unused config options

There are several historical cut/paste unused options, which have
also now found there way into heat.conf.sample, which will confuse
users, so best to remove them.

Fixes bug #1215834

Change-Id: I0fe4717327fc67fe109bef4ba1758d2f18e84520

following traceback while running with python3:

Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
python3: Fix UserString import

In python3 UserString got moved to collections. This results in the
following traceback while running with python3:

ImportError: No module named 'UserString'

Change-Id: Ica44cd027e012e13828c0a84b3b36607cc92fe69
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Skip devstack/exercises by default

In order to avoid maintaining test cases in two location,
the devstack/exercises should be disabled when tempest is enabled.

The exercises is preserved for grande and stable branch jobs.

A smaller/faster 'smoke' test case set can be selected from the tempest
test cases if it is needed.

Fixing bug #1023131

Change-Id: Icac3998fb2c18274d909afcff8708af149d68197

requests raises subclass of requests.exception.RequestException, not
IOError. And the code explicitly calls raise_for_status to avoid HTTP
errors being silently ignored.

Change-Id: Ib3ea7e4fea459a231f0bb7f113e3d66983b006c2
'}]
commit_message:
Process request exceptions while fetching template

requests raises subclass of requests.exception.RequestException, not
IOError. And the code explicitly calls raise_for_status to avoid HTTP
errors being silently ignored.

Fixes bug #1214429

Change-Id: Ib3ea7e4fea459a231f0bb7f113e3d66983b006c2

commit_message:
Use system locale when Accept-Language header is not provided

Remove en_US as the default language when no header is provided, and use
None instead. Upon translation None will be defaulted to system as it
was before the translation changes.

Fixes bug: #1214476

Change-Id: I0fe22c526710e69ae0731e7d0b42170e6f3a8523

[{'created': '2013-08-21 13:12:25.000000000', 'message': "Fix incorrect use of ServerError

ServerError is being incorrectly used to report an internal error
leading to an error formatting the response, as there's no body
specified to the format string.  Use exception.Error instead and
adjust the message to make the user-visible response clearer.

Fixes bug #1214457

Change-Id: I83435686170c4f40658968a35f1faa303f50f4a4
"}]
commit_message:
Fix incorrect use of ServerError

ServerError is being incorrectly used to report an internal error
leading to an error formatting the response, as there's no body
specified to the format string.  Use exception.Error instead and
adjust the message to make the user-visible response clearer.

Fixes bug #1214457

Change-Id: I83435686170c4f40658968a35f1faa303f50f4a4

commit_message:

a25d888c914b417b2e7fba9bd497088b22a46309 broke install.sh due

commit_message:
Move sections of nova.conf into partials

Moved larger sections of nova.conf into partials.  Also, attempted
to categorize flags that were in the wrong place.  I would concider
this a stepping stone to oslo.

Change-Id: I199a03d5d8cae4b20efcbad6ded9cfa8fb61aa67

commit_message:
Use elevated context as intended

Rectoring introduced in Id8f81419fbbc3616e216e4da0c16898757905933
was not quite complete, and it missed to change the context needed
to create and destroy the metadata network.

Fix bug #1216110

Change-Id: I2161b07f5cd09654f714e237cb4277e8bc60fff1

commit_message:
Pass owner_id to stack_get_by_name()

The heat.db.sqlalchemy.api supports this parameters, but heat.db.api did
not.

commit_message:
Add a method of creating a backup stack in the DB

This is a temporary storage place for resources that are going to be
deleted once their replacements are created. They must be moved out of
the stack in order to avoid conflicting with the replacement resource.

Change-Id: I081498f4c8732f893dc0d0677cf2b3f40f56d808

commit_message:
Allow a Provider with a known facade its own schema

Allow a TemplateResource behind the facade of a known plugin to supply a
different schema to the facade resource. However, check during validation
that the two are basically compatible. The provider template must:

- Define parameters for all *required* properties of the facade.
- Define parameters that map to the same types as the facade properties.
- Not have *required* parameters that do not exist in the facade.
- Define outputs for all attributes of the facade.

Change-Id: Ie40ecbb43d3d6749266f2cb6d723c8537fcc23dd

in tests. This patch also fixes problems which are manifested right
after the enablement of lazy translation in tests.

Fixes bug #1208454

commit_message:
Evaluate lazy translation in exception __str__

The OpenStackException.__str__ method returns
self._error_string which is actually a gettextutil.Message
object not a str.

str(o) will check the return type of o.__str__() and raise
TypeError if __str__ returns non-string object.

The fix will not go into oslo as OpenStackException is
about to be deprecated. And this patch is also the first
step to remove all the references to oslo exception.py.

Fixes bug #1208454

Change-Id: Ib6abe3517bcb1b34fc6a71e5c46ee3774e067f9a

commit_message:
Do not obscure Unauthorized error messages

All Unauthorized exceptions are currently trapped and
the following message is printed:
    Invalid OpenStack Identity credentials.

This is unhelpful now that heat-api is providing structured
errors with (sometimes) helpful context for authorization failures.

This change removes this error trapping and prints the intended
error message.

Change-Id: Ibd943deb1f365e5f212225be1e675beb14accf97

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-19 08:39:12.000000000', 'message': 'Fixed a network setup issue for F19

IP address is passed as a kernel boot param when booting undercloud
machine. For Fedora 19, this IP is not set, instead IP is fetched
from DHCP.

The problem is caused by a bug in dracut-network version 029, which
causes that dracut network setup script is not executed properly. This
patch applies a fix for the bug when building undercloud image.

Fixes: bug #1213833
Change-Id: Ie94a86ed716044343791628973143c1a7d0778dc
'}]
commit_message:
Fixed a network setup issue for F19

IP address is passed as a kernel boot param when booting undercloud
machine. For Fedora 19, this IP is not set, instead IP is fetched
from DHCP.

The problem is caused by a bug in dracut-network version 029, which
causes that dracut network setup script is not executed properly. This
patch applies a fix for the bug when building undercloud image.

Fixes: bug #1213833
Change-Id: Ie94a86ed716044343791628973143c1a7d0778dc

commit_message:
Handling re-delete in rackspace db resource

Current implementation of db resource throws exception if the
resource was already deleted(All the other resources are not
throwing). This fix is to make db resource behavior similar to
other resources.

Fixes Bug #1197077

Change-Id: I4537180115400e6f6183e72a74bdd3ada220a3fa

commit_message:
Replace httplib with requests for ec2tokens auth

This vastly simplifies the implementation and test mocking.

ec2token middleware is the last piece of code in the heat
repository to be making direct httplib calls.

Change-Id: I3807b27a7699ff19eb46e2721aaa5afd9d6c8ff9

commit_message:
Support array values in command

Description of command in CFN User Guide:

Either an array or a string specifying the command to run. If you use
an array, you do not need to escape space characters or enclose
command parameters in quotes.

So we escape double quote first, and enclose each array value in
double quote.

Fixes bug #1211605

Change-Id: I28ecdb0d4b8a12690dddeac4e2398264c6d6f212

commit_message:
remove flake8 option from run_tests.sh

flake8 will read the section [flake8] of tox.ini to guide the
behavior. In run_tests.sh, the function run_flake8() does not
need the falke8 option any more.

Fixes Bug #1214159
Change-Id: I1bbba279a339e35c776a6969598b398f57fd7646

(2 inline comments)

This is a good catch Stuart.  

Some background info fwiw -
I think there is an underlying bug in a recent commit for multiple-image-locations - both create/update in glance.registry.api.v1.images attempt to convert a "location" header to "locations" (https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/registry/api/v1/images.py#L394) but don't count on the fact that may already be set.  _normalize_image_location_for_db is then adding each letter in the string as a location to the image_locations table.

Summary, the above could be fixed, but your approach of locking down headers will do the trick and should be done regardless.  Have just added two small suggestions in-line.'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-07-31 15:47:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

headers. Attempts to supply other, unexpected headers

Add a whitelist of allowed 'x-image-meta-xxx' style
headers. Attempts to supply other, unexpected headers
will return 400.

This prevents cases such as 'x-image-meta-locations'

Change-Id: I771bb6ae2a4f9cbd7726f952c7a71da99162b490

commit_message:
Add v1 API x-image-meta- header whitelist

Add a whitelist of allowed 'x-image-meta-xxx' style
headers. Attempts to supply other, unexpected headers
will return 400.

This prevents cases such as 'x-image-meta-locations'
being processed, which were not being handled correctly.

Addresses bug 1205018.

Change-Id: I771bb6ae2a4f9cbd7726f952c7a71da99162b490

I'm going to drop this change.

While talking to Dan Smith, he made me realize you can easily accomplish the same goal by running the existing nova-api service with different configuration.  You can configure it on another port if you want, and of course, a different set of API extensions.

There is some work that could be done to make it easier to deploy common sets of API extensions (the existing *everything* default for the admin case, and just end user stuff for the public case). commit_message:
Add an admin API endpoint

Add an admin API endpoint to Nova.  This is intended to be an endpoint
only exposed internally to the deployment.  It will be used for
integration with other services, such as Cinder or Neutron.

By default, the admin API listens on port 35359.  When adding
information to the Keystone service catalog, this new port should be
used for the adminURL.

As of this commit, the API exposed by this endpoint is identical to that
of the regular API.  However, hooks are provided for adding admin API
endpoint specific API extensions.  This will be utilized in future
commits.

Implements blueprint admin-api

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ib9c22cd970d598b34618d9c91c779477aa1d4004

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-08-25 10:46:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Thanks Gary, but marking this for translation is a waste of translators time - it is only used during unit tests and we don't use translations during unit testing"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-08-25 11:52:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I was under the impression that this was an auto generated script. So if I understand you correctly then tests should not have any translations. If so then why did the raise here have text.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-08-25 11:59:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I was under the impression that this was an auto generated script.

What "this" is an auto-generated script?

> So if I understand you correctly then tests should not have any translations.

Messages marked for translation do not get translated at runtime during tests.

> If so then why did the raise here have text.

Because the text is useful to people running the unit tests.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-08-25 13:02:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

There is a script run (not sure how and when) but this updates all of the relevant tests. You can look at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/41292/ for an example.
That is "this" script.
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-08-25 13:02:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

s/tests/texts'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-08-25 13:03:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Maybe this may be addressed by someone else in the future. Just seems like it is not relevant at this stage'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-08-25 13:57:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The transifex jenkins job just updates the .pot and .po files with strings from the current source and merges in any new translations the translators may have added in transifex: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Translations#Re-incorporating_Translations

The "waste of translators time" point is that each new string we add appears on transifex as a string for translators to manually translate.

Adding strings that are never used at runtime is a waste of the volunteer translators time.'}]

'}]
commit_message:
Update Unavailable Url

In file:nova/virt/libvirt/imagecache.py, the wiki url
about Nova-image-cache-management can not redirect to
the right place, so update the unavailable wiki url.

Change-Id: I2396cf51c5ed1ccb01f4ef566f022b9e50c172cc

Clean up the sqlalchemy migrate manage.py script.

This way we can run it without figuring out passing in
the correct url and repository information.

flake8 read [flake8] section of tox.ini as options.

function run_flake8 in run_tests.sh should be kept simple,
and tox.ini controls the behavior of flake8.

commit_message:
remove flake8 option in run_tests.sh

flake8 read [flake8] section of tox.ini as options.

function run_flake8 in run_tests.sh should be kept simple,
and tox.ini controls the behavior of flake8.

Fixes Bug #1212988

Change-Id: I35d434ccea1ca2f3ff93657e4ca6dde93bbbf29e

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-16 05:52:14.000000000', 'message': 'flake8 check: H233 the print operator

As the H233 checking is added into Python package "hacking",
the print operator problem is exposed.

H233:
Check that all occurrences look like print functions, not
print operator.

As of Python 3.x, the print operator has been removed.

Okay: print(msg)
Okay: print (msg)
H233: print msg
H233: print >>sys.stderr, "hello"
H233: print msg,

Fix the print operator and the consequent falke8 issues, and
enable H233 in tox.ini.

Fixes Bug #1211130

Change-Id: I52554692717b22fc0bfea56e62e9f87756cc5b16
'}]
commit_message:
flake8 check: H233 the print operator

As the H233 checking is added into Python package "hacking",
the print operator problem is exposed.

H233:
Check that all occurrences look like print functions, not
print operator.

As of Python 3.x, the print operator has been removed.

Okay: print(msg)
Okay: print (msg)
H233: print msg
H233: print >>sys.stderr, "hello"
H233: print msg,

Fix the print operator and the consequent falke8 issues, and
enable H233 in tox.ini.

Fixes Bug #1211130

Change-Id: I52554692717b22fc0bfea56e62e9f87756cc5b16

commit_message:
Storwize/SVC: allow setting of I/O group

Allow setting the I/O group via config option or volume type. Also
updated comments and checks regarding iSCSI multipath, which is in Nova
and is not controlled by the driver.

Fixes: bug 1215363

Change-Id: Ia67fcb9991e21990cc81830145b8fd934a23488e

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-21 11:13:29.000000000', 'message': 'emit warning while running flake8 without virtual env

run_tests.sh -N -p
it will call the flake8 installed on your host to detect PEP8, and
the flake8 plugin "OpenStack hacking" may not installed on your
host, so this command may not detect the OpenStack Style Commandment
supplied by hacking(e.g H202).

run_tests.sh -p
it will call the flake8 from virtual env, flake8 plugin "OpenStack
hacking" installed in virtual env will be triggered.

The result from "run_tests.sh -p" should be trusted, and jenkins uses
virtual env to run flake8 too.

When "-N" is enabled, emit warning to remind user.

Bug #1208584

Change-Id: Ie08e5fa2b44088dad135e11583c046650d65df1e
'}]
commit_message:
emit warning while running flake8 without virtual env

run_tests.sh -N -p
it will call the flake8 installed on your host to detect PEP8, and
the flake8 plugin "OpenStack hacking" may not installed on your
host, so this command may not detect the OpenStack Style Commandment
supplied by hacking(e.g H202).

run_tests.sh -p
it will call the flake8 from virtual env, flake8 plugin "OpenStack
hacking" installed in virtual env will be triggered.

The result from "run_tests.sh -p" should be trusted, and jenkins uses
virtual env to run flake8 too.

When "-N" is enabled, emit warning to remind user.

Bug #1208584

Change-Id: Ie08e5fa2b44088dad135e11583c046650d65df1e

commit_message:
Fix volume_glance_metadata deletion

If volume_glance_metadata does not exist for a certain volume,
it returns an exception and does not delete volume from db.
Avoid deleting it if it does not exist.

Bug: 1209367
Change-Id: Ia607ec5ecfc115c1a593f14236ee93158938a8da

commit_message:
Use a new rest client for every Coraid ESM command

It's workaround for the session corruption bug
in the ESM Appliance.

fix bug #1214433

Change-Id: Ie844f3c95675c4d734390c23ed2d421c159ce8a7

[{'created': '2013-08-24 15:59:26.000000000', 'message': 'Remove print statement in db api test

Remove the encryption related print statements in
test_dp_api, this should bring us up to speed
now for updated requirements and take care of the
py3.3 incompat print issues.

Change-Id: If7475cc43d3c0b443908f846d76071913536fdf4
'}]
commit_message:
Remove print statement in db api test

Remove the encryption related print statements in
test_dp_api, this should bring us up to speed
now for updated requirements and take care of the
py3.3 incompat print issues.

Change-Id: If7475cc43d3c0b443908f846d76071913536fdf4

'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-05-22 04:40:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So I'll apologize for the -1, it's more to get some thought around this.  

I like what you've done and the approach you took, a couple of thoughts however when thinking about long-term evolution and some of the existing things we're doing with types/extra-specs.

First, I like the idea of adding fields to the types table like you've done here.  I'm wondering if we can take this a little further and incorporate some of the other common (and not so common) performance type characteristics here.  For example, we have max_read/write and iops, while some drivers use extra specs to set these as QoS levels.

Would it make sense to make these more broadly available?  I'm also assuming based on what's here so far that these values are going to be hidden from the end user correct?

To make this work in the broader case I think we could add a n entry that's something like: "backend-implemented=True/False" (where False indicates use the hypervisor).

I also think we need to be clear that these are thresholds, not necessarily capabilities, that's not really an issue as it stands if it's only hypervisor rate-limiting but there should be some clarification and if we consider combining the QoS settings others are currently working on, or have implemented we might want to factor some things in to handle that as well.'}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-05-23 17:17:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

For rate limits, we should probably have one mechanism for users to specify them, but maybe the admin should choose where it is done (i.e., hypervisor, back-end, etc)?  In a deployment with SolidFire, for example, would it make sense to impose rate limits at the hypervisor level because it's more "end-to-end" (i.e., covers the network as well), and do min and burst (and maybe also max) at the storage?

Also, if these terms (i.e., write_iops_sec, total_bytes_sec) are user-visible, and can be implemented by different mechanisms, we need to settle on some common language.'}, {'account_id': 6043, 'date': '2013-05-23 17:32:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

FWIW...regarding the rate limits for the HP 3PAR arrays, the definition that we came up with is as follows:
- Max IO/S(total_iops_sec) & Max MB/S(total_bytes_sec) are not QoS guarantees. 
- These are per volume maximums which the 3PAR is guaranteed not to exceed.
- Settings these values does not guarantee these performance rates will be achievable.
Also, these values can be set on a per volume basis.'}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-05-23 17:51:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Kurt - that seems similar to what KVM provides, except for separating read and write.  Correct?

Do we want to do the least common denominator?  Opinions?'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2013-05-24 02:08:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Avishay, I'd say this kind of limits (or boarder scope: perf characteristics) is _not_ visible to end user. And I agree that when admin specifies such parameters, he/she may also have to specify two other things: 1) how he/she would want Cinder to interpret these parameters. For example, total_iops_sec could be just a upper bound of IOPS while it's also possible to be considered as a performance assurance requirement (QoS guarantee). 2) where (client or back-end) he/she would like to have such control be enforced.
For 1), I think there are roughly 3 types or levels of meanings of the parameter: rate_limit, best effort, guarantee. It's obvious that latter two types must depend on back-ends to achieve such goal while rate_limit could be done in either (or both) side of the connection. Please refer to my writing of this whole big idea of using volume type for (not just) rate_limit and performance assurance: https://etherpad.openstack.org/cinder-extend-volume-types"}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2013-05-24 02:45:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

John, Avishay and Kurt,

I'm worried about the actual progress of implementing a useful feature as I think more about potential use cases of extending volume type with performance characteristics.  I feel like I've opened the Pandora box. :)  

While I agree we should/can achieve more with those parameters in my patch, I think we should take steps to move forward.  Here's my proposal:

1) [rate_limit, client side control only]add parameters to describe bandwidth/IOPS to volume type table and only use it for client side rate_limit;  <-- at this point, we can have a usable feature.

2) [extend to support other level of performance control, enable back-ends control logic]add perf_control_level/location to volume type; (please refer to https://etherpad.openstack.org/cinder-extend-volume-types for perf_control_level/location), when we figure out how back-ends report standardized performance assurance capabilities.

What do you think?"}, {'account_id': 6043, 'date': '2013-05-24 17:41:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I think you did a great job with the recent changes to cover the majority of the possibilities. This will meet the needs of the 3PAR backends. Is this going to make it into H1? I hope as I need to build my solution around it for H2.'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2013-05-28 12:48:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

My thoughts on this are that we shouldn't start overloading the volume types table, that is just going to get really messy as we add more features that are abstracted behind a voume type.

I started to put down my thoughts about a better model at https://etherpad.openstack.org/cinder-volume-types-evolution - feel free to comment/edit/add"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-05 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

So first off this is awesome work.  I have a number of concerns however and I've made a few comments regarding those concerns inline.

I'm concerned about the approach of having defined columns like we're doing here.  I don't think any two vendors are doing qos the same way or using the same definitions, I could be wrong I'd be curious to see what other interface implementations look like.

The main concern I have though is I don't see it as sustainable, trying to have an entry for every possible setting/value that somebody may choose to implement.  The alternative I proposed was to use dynamic K/V, I made a number of notes about this inline in models.py"}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-06-07 04:33:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-20 05:45:49.000000000', 'message': "Add rate limit columns to volume_types table

This is part of the effort to implement client-side volume rate limiting
feature. The idea of client-side volume rate limiting is quite simple: Cinder
stores rate-limiting parameters in for each volume, and then when Nova asks
for connection infomration of volume, Cinder sends back rate limiting
parameters so that Nova can apply to its side via virtualization layer. Take
KVM hypervisor (or libvirt virt layer) for example: with libvirt later than
0.9.8, it's able to put following rate limit controls of a block device for
VM:

  * total_bytes_sec: total throughput limit in bytes per second. This cannot
    appear with read_bytes_sec or write_bytes_sec.
  * read_bytes_sec: read throughput limit in bytes per second.
  * write_bytes_sec: write throughput limit in bytes per second.

  * total_iops_sec: total I/O operations per second. This cannot appear with
    read_iops_sec or write_iops_sec.
  * read_iops_sec: read I/O operations per second.
  * write_iops_sec: write I/O operations per second.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of rate limit
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design in this patch is to bond rate limiting with volume
types. So Cinder admin can create various volume types with different rate
limit controls, and volumes of same volume type have same rate limit
parameters.

To store rate limit parameters with volume types also have two different
options: 1) extend volume type table itself and add new columns for rate limit;
2) use volume_type_extra_spec to store rate limit parameters. While the latter
design seems to have lowest impact of Cinder code, it does bring in new
challenges: Cinder volume manager needs an fixed way (i.e. doesn't reply on how
admin create a volume type) to retrieve rate limiting parameters for volumes,
but extra specs are dynamic by nature (all defined by admin). Therefore, this
patch takes first approach to store rate limiting paramenters, that's adding
new columns to volume_types table. It's generic description of how client (and
/or back-end) should limit throughput/IOPS of volumes, and by default, all rate
limiting parameters are set to zero, which means there's no rate limit of
existing volumes.

This patch changes the internal API interface for creating volume types, so no
impact of compatibility at all. The rest part of the changes needed in Cinder
are:
 * enable volume manager/driver to read and send rate limit parameters to Nova
 in initliaize_connection() call;
 * allow type_manage API extension to process rate limit parameters;
 * enable cinder client to process rate limit parameters when creating new
 volume types.

DocImpact

partically implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

Change-Id: Iabc61b941aaff10395b30e2045e3421369a317e2

0.9.8, it's able to put following rate limit controls of a block device for
VM:

  * total_bytes_sec: total throughput limit in bytes per second. This cannot
    appear with read_bytes_sec or write_bytes_sec.
  * read_bytes_sec: read throughput limit in bytes per second.
  * write_bytes_sec: write throughput limit in bytes per second.

  * total_iops_sec: total I/O operations per second. This cannot appear with
    read_iops_sec or write_iops_sec.
  * read_iops_sec: read I/O operations per second.
  * write_iops_sec: write I/O operations per second.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of rate limit
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design in this patch is to bond rate limiting with volume
types. So Cinder admin can create various volume types with different rate
limit controls, and volumes of same volume type have same rate limit
parameters.

To store rate limit parameters with volume types also have two different
options: 1) extend volume type table itself and add new columns for rate limit;
2) use volume_type_extra_spec to store rate limit parameters. While the latter
design seems to have lowest impact of Cinder code, it does bring in new
challenges: Cinder volume manager needs an fixed way (i.e. doesn't reply on how
admin create a volume type) to retrieve rate limiting parameters for volumes,
but extra specs are dynamic by nature (all defined by admin). Therefore, this
patch takes first approach to store rate limiting paramenters, that's adding
new columns to volume_types table. It's generic description of how client (and
/or back-end) should limit throughput/IOPS of volumes, and by default, all rate
limiting parameters are set to zero, which means there's no rate limit of
existing volumes.

This patch changes the internal API interface for creating volume types, so no
impact of compatibility at all. The rest part of the changes needed in Cinder
are:
 * enable volume manager/driver to read and send rate limit parameters to Nova
 in initliaize_connection() call;
 * enable cinder client to process rate limit parameters when creating new
 volume types.

DocImpact

partically implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

Change-Id: Iabc61b941aaff10395b30e2045e3421369a317e2

"}, {'created': '2013-06-05 20:32:59.000000000', 'message': "Implement QoS support for volumes

This patch is to implement generic Quality-of-Service(QoS) support for volumes.
While QoS can mean a lot things, here in this implementation it mainly refers
to throttling/rate-limiting and performance assurance. The goal is 1) to add an
interface so that cloud/Cinder admins can use to express QoS requirements for
volumes; 2) to define common performance characteristics for volume; 3) to
change scheduler so that it can filter out unqualified back-ends.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of QoS control
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design is to bond QoS with volume types. So Cinder admin
can create various volume types with different QoS requirements, and volumes
of same volume type share the same QoS specifications.

Changes:
  - Add a quality_of_services table to accommadate QoS requirements for volume
  types. Follow eight fields are used to describe performance characteristics:
    * total_bytes_sec: total throughput limit in bytes per second. This cannot
      appear with read_bytes_sec or write_bytes_sec.
    * read_bytes_sec: read throughput limit in bytes per second.
    * write_bytes_sec: write throughput limit in bytes per second.

    * total_iops_sec: total I/O operations per second. This cannot appear with
      read_iops_sec or write_iops_sec.
    * read_iops_sec: read I/O operations per second.
    * write_iops_sec: write I/O operations per second.

    Two additional keys:
    * 'qos_type' key is to describe the levels of QoS: rate-limit, best effort
      perf assurance and perf guarantee.
    * 'control_location' is to store the value where admin would like the QoS
      policy to be enforced.
  - Add 'volume_type_qos' API extension to allow mofication of type QoS.
  - Add 'supported_QoS_types' to host capabilities, lvm/solidfire driver
  changes are made as an example.
  - Add 'qos_specs' to filter properties for a volume create request.
  - Add QoSFilter for filter scheduler.

TODO:
  Add unittests.

DocImpact

implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

Change-Id: Iabc61b941aaff10395b30e2045e3421369a317e2

"}, {'created': '2013-07-18 17:48:22.000000000', 'message': "Implement QoS support for volumes

This patch is to implement generic Quality-of-Service(QoS) support for volumes.
The goal is 1) to add an interface so that cloud/Cinder admins can use to set
volume rate-limit, which can be enforced either in hypervisor or on Cinder
back-end or both; 2) to add an interface so that admins can use to express
QoS requirements for volumes (of specific back-ends), which will be consumed
by back-end drivers.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of QoS control
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design is to bond QoS with volume types. So Cinder admin
can create various volume types with different QoS requirements, and volumes
of same volume type share the same QoS specifications.

QoS can mean a lot different things that it's unlikely we can come up with a
intepreation that all vendors can agree on.  On the other hand, the
throttling/rate-limiting is a notion that has clear defintion that everyone
agrees on. So the approach this implementation takes is to break Quality-of-
Service into two parts: throttling/rate-limiting and the rest (free-form,
vender specific defintion).  The free-form part is stored as key/value pairs
as special (under the scope 'QoS_specs:') extra_specs of a volume type, and
the rate-limit control info is stored as part of specification for types (as
new columns for volume_types table).

Changes:
 - Add following 7 columns to volume_types table for rate-limit requirements
 for volume types.
  * total_bytes_sec: total throughput limit in bytes per second. This cannot
 appear with read_bytes_sec or write_bytes_sec.
  * read_bytes_sec: read throughput limit in bytes per second.
  * write_bytes_sec: write throughput limit in bytes per second.

  * total_iops_sec: total I/O operations per second. This cannot appear with
 read_iops_sec or write_iops_sec.
  * read_iops_sec: read I/O operations per second.
  * write_iops_sec: write I/O operations per second.

  * 'control_location' is to store the value where admin would like the QoS
 policy to be enforced, currently these three values are considered valid:
 'front-end' (Nova Compute), 'back-end' (Cinder back-end), 'both'.

 - Add a new resource extension to 'types_extra_specs' API extension to allow
 list/create/update/delete of type QoS specs.
 - Modify 'type_manage' API extension to be able to accept rate_limit info.
 - Modify volume_types.create() to accept rate-limit info and do the checks.
 - Add 'qos_specs' to request_specs and filter properties for a volume
 create request.
 - Add rate-limit info to data structure when initialize_connection()

DocImpact

implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

Change-Id: Iabc61b941aaff10395b30e2045e3421369a317e2

 create request.

"}, {'created': '2013-07-24 10:10:56.000000000', 'message': "Implement QoS support for volumes

This patch is to implement generic Quality-of-Service(QoS) support for volumes.
The goal is 1) to add an interface so that cloud/Cinder admins can use to set
volume rate-limit, which can be enforced either in hypervisor or on Cinder
back-end or both; 2) to add an interface so that admins can use to express
QoS requirements for volumes (of specific back-ends), which will be consumed
by back-end drivers.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of QoS control
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design is to bond QoS with volume types. So Cinder admin
can create various volume types with different QoS requirements, and volumes
of same volume type share the same QoS specifications.

QoS can mean a lot different things that it's unlikely we can come up with a
intepreation that all vendors can agree on.  On the other hand, the
throttling/rate-limiting is a notion that has clear defintion that everyone
agrees on. So the approach this implementation takes is to break Quality-of-
Service into two parts: throttling/rate-limiting and the rest (free-form,
vender specific defintion).  The free-form part is stored as key/value pairs
as special (under the scope 'QoS_specs:') extra_specs of a volume type, and
the rate-limit control info is stored in a new table called
volume_type_rate_limit.

Changes:
 - Add a volume_type_rate_limit table with following 7 columns to store
 rate-limit requirements for volume types.  Note that unlike extra_specs,
 there's only one rate limit entry per volume type if any, since the rate_limit
 control information has fixed keys.

  * total_bytes_sec: total throughput limit in bytes per second.
  * read_bytes_sec: read throughput limit in bytes per second.
  * write_bytes_sec: write throughput limit in bytes per second.

  * total_iops_sec: total I/O operations per second.
  * read_iops_sec: read I/O operations per second.
  * write_iops_sec: write I/O operations per second.

  * 'control_location' is to store the value where admin would like the QoS
 policy to be enforced, currently these three values are considered valid:
 'front-end' (Nova Compute), 'back-end' (Cinder back-end), 'both'.

 - Add a new resource extension to 'types_extra_specs' API extension to allow
 list/create/update/delete of type QoS specs.
 - Modify 'type_manage' API extension to be able to accept rate_limit info.
 - Modify volume_types.create() to accept rate-limit info and do the checks.
 - Add 'qos_specs' and 'rate_limit' to request_specs and filter properties for
 a volume create request.
 - Add 'rate_limit', 'qos_specs' info to data structure when
 initialize_connection() is called.

DocImpact

implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

Change-Id: Iabc61b941aaff10395b30e2045e3421369a317e2

"}, {'created': '2013-08-07 18:04:15.000000000', 'message': "Implement QoS support for volumes

This patch is to implement generic Quality-of-Service(QoS) support for volumes.
The goal is to add an interface so that cloud/Cinder admins can use to set
volume QoS, which can be enforced either in hypervisor or on Cinder back-end
or both. QoS specifications are added as a standalone (only visible to admin)
entity.  So admin can create/update/delete and associate/disassociate QoS
specifications to other entities, in this case volume types.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of QoS control
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design is to bond QoS with volume types. So Cinder admin
can associate volume types with QoS specifications, and volumes of same volume
type share the same QoS specifications.

QoS can mean a lot different things that it's unlikely we can come up with a
interpretation that all vendors can agree on.  So the approach this
implementation takes is to make Quality-of-Service specs as free-from, i.e.
expressed as key/value pairs.

Changes:
 - Add a quality_of_service_specs table, using adjacency list relation to store
 a specs entry and its detailed specs in key/values. Note that to be able to
 distinguish where should the QoS specs be consumed, each QoS specs entity
 will have a 'consumer' (i.e. fixed key) with the value of where admin would
 like the QoS policy to be enforced/consumed, currently these three values are
 considered valid: 'front-end' (Nova Compute), 'back-end' (Cinder back-end),
 'both'. The default value for 'consumer' is 'back-end'.

 - Add a new API extension 'qos_specs_manage' to allow list/create/update/
 delete/associate/disassociate of QoS specs.

 TODO
 - Modify 'type_manage' API extension to be able to accept rate_limit info.
 - Modify volume_types.create() to accept rate-limit info and do the checks.
 - Add 'qos_specs' and 'rate_limit' to request_specs and filter properties for
 a volume create request.
 - Add 'rate_limit', 'qos_specs' info to data structure when
 initialize_connection() is called.

DocImpact

implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

Change-Id: Iabc61b941aaff10395b30e2045e3421369a317e2

"}, {'created': '2013-08-23 02:47:39.000000000', 'message': "Implement QoS support for volumes

This patch is to implement generic Quality-of-Service(QoS) support for volumes.
The goal is to add an interface so that cloud/Cinder admins can use to set
volume QoS, which can be enforced either in hypervisor or on Cinder back-end
or both. QoS specifications are added as a standalone (only visible to admin)
entity.  So admin can create/update/delete and associate/disassociate QoS
specifications to other entities, in this case volume types.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of QoS control
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design is to bond QoS with volume types. So Cinder admin
can associate volume types with QoS specifications, and volumes of same volume
type share the same QoS specifications.

QoS can mean a lot different things that it's unlikely we can come up with a
interpretation that all vendors can agree on.  So the approach this
implementation takes is to make Quality-of-Service specs as free-from, i.e.
expressed as key/value pairs.

Changes:
 - Add a quality_of_service_specs table, using adjacency list relation to store
 a specs entry and its detailed specs in key/values. Note that to be able to
 distinguish where should the QoS specs be consumed, each QoS specs entity
 will have a 'consumer' (i.e. fixed key) with the value of where admin would
 like the QoS policy to be enforced/consumed, currently these three values are
 considered valid: 'front-end' (Nova Compute), 'back-end' (Cinder back-end),
 'both'. The default value for 'consumer' is 'back-end';
 - Add a new API extension 'qos_specs_manage' to allow list/create/update/
 delete/associate/disassociate of QoS specs;
 - Add volume/qos_specs internal API for qos specs manipulation;
 - Add 'qos_specs' info to data structure when
 initialize_connection() is called.
 - Add 'qos_specs' to request_specs and filter properties for
 a volume create request.

 TODO
 - Modify 'type_manage' API extension to be able to accept qos info.
 - Modify volume_types.create() to accept qos info and do the checks.

DocImpact

implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

Change-Id: Iabc61b941aaff10395b30e2045e3421369a317e2

commit_message:
Implement QoS support for volumes

This patch is to implement generic Quality-of-Service(QoS) support for volumes.
The goal is to add an interface so that cloud/Cinder admins can use to set
volume QoS, which can be enforced either in hypervisor or on Cinder back-end
or both. QoS specifications are added as a standalone (only visible to admin)
entity.  So admin can create/update/delete and associate/disassociate QoS
specifications to other entities, in this case volume types.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of QoS control
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design is to bond QoS with volume types. So Cinder admin
can associate volume types with QoS specifications, and volumes of same volume
type share the same QoS specifications.

QoS can mean a lot different things that it's unlikely we can come up with a
interpretation that all vendors can agree on.  So the approach this
implementation takes is to make Quality-of-Service specs as free-from, i.e.
expressed as key/value pairs.

Changes:
 - Add a quality_of_service_specs table, using adjacency list relation to store
 a specs entry and its detailed specs in key/values. Note that to be able to
 distinguish where should the QoS specs be consumed, each QoS specs entity
 will have a 'consumer' (i.e. fixed key) with the value of where admin would
 like the QoS policy to be enforced/consumed, currently these three values are
 considered valid: 'front-end' (Nova Compute), 'back-end' (Cinder back-end),
 'both'. The default value for 'consumer' is 'back-end';
 - Add a new API extension 'qos_specs_manage' to allow list/create/update/
 delete/associate/disassociate of QoS specs;
 - Add volume/qos_specs internal API for qos specs manipulation;
 - Add 'qos_specs' info to data structure when
 initialize_connection() is called.
 - Add 'qos_specs' to request_specs and filter properties for
 a volume create request.

 TODO
 - Modify 'type_manage' API extension to be able to accept qos info.
 - Modify volume_types.create() to accept qos info and do the checks.

DocImpact

implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

Change-Id: Iabc61b941aaff10395b30e2045e3421369a317e2

commit_message:
Downgrade subunit

Closes-Bug: #1216231

Sync with openstack/requirements.

Since subunit has released its new version 0.0.14, run tox -epy27
will cause 'unpack requires a string argument of length 1' error
and fail to run unittest. And Jenkins cannot work well too.

We should downgrage it to 0.0.13 untill subunit fix this problem.

Change-Id: Iedaf3422a7b50697225cae495c3202a8e4230889

commit_message:
Downgrade subunit

Closes-Bug: #1216231

Sync with openstack/requirements.

Since subunit has released its new version 0.0.14, run tox -epy27
will cause 'unpack requires a string argument of length 1' error
and fail to run unittest. And Jenkins cannot work well too.

We should downgrage it to 0.0.13 untill subunit fix this problem.

Change-Id: I6d71f86427b6a8906c76fd8fc410e62acd355b2a

[{'created': '2013-08-16 12:50:48.000000000', 'message': "Ensure that setup_requires are installed

When setup.py uses easy_install to resolve dependencies, it downloads an
egg into the local dir. Additionally, when python is invoked via
sys.executable and not via a #! line, it prepends '' to sys.path. This
means that when pbr shells out to pip to install install_requirements,
it will consider any locally downloaded eggs to be installed, and so
will erroneously not install them.

To avoid this, make the pip invocation slightly more complex, and strip
'' out of sys.path in the invocation. This should mean that eggs in the
local dir will always be ignored for the purposes of resolving
dependencies, which is the correct behavior.

Change-Id: Ic5254396b71b9d3f3f71236d65024125817ddd08
"}, {'created': '2013-08-18 02:53:57.000000000', 'message': "Ensure that setup_requires are installed

commit_message:
Ensure that setup_requires are installed

When setup.py uses easy_install to resolve dependencies, it downloads an
egg into the local dir. Additionally, when python is invoked via
sys.executable and not via a #! line, it prepends '' to sys.path. This
means that when pbr shells out to pip to install install_requirements,
it will consider any locally downloaded eggs to be installed, and so
will erroneously not install them.

To avoid this, make the pip invocation slightly more complex, and strip
'' out of sys.path in the invocation. This should mean that eggs in the
local dir will always be ignored for the purposes of resolving
dependencies, which is the correct behavior.

Change-Id: Ic5254396b71b9d3f3f71236d65024125817ddd08

"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-08-03 16:59:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

My initial test of this revealed some dependencies that are still missing.  Keystone required:

Routes (not sure why this wasn't installed)

Not listed in any requirements.txt, should have been caught by other prereqs?):
decorator (apt==3.3.2, pip==3.4.0)
tempita

lxml 3.2.3 build fails... (apt==2.3.2)
lxml==2.3.2 build fails, installing apt, has no otherwise uninstalled python-* dependencies

now keystone starts.

I think we can't just remove everything, but should have a good reason (like lxml has) to use the package rather than pypi version."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-08-03 17:18:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

An idea that devstack might be able to take from what anvil is doing.

Instead of ignoring the distro's packages completely anvil has taken the approach
that it will scan the distro repo and attempt to use the distros packages
(rpm repos in anvils case - at the current time) only if the versions will
correctly work with the provided pypi requirements.

The main program that helps do this validation that might just be able to be
duplicated or used in devstack (with a corresponding apt compatible version
also)

https://github.com/stackforge/anvil/blob/master/tools/yumfind

  $ ./tools/yumfind  -p 'python-setuptools,setuptools>0.8,<1'
  python-setuptools-0.9.8-0.el6.noarch

For pypi packages that can not be found (or have incompat. version matches) then
will anvil go ahead and attempt to download said missing requirements and build
those into rpms (this build into rpm devstack could avoid since it can just
install them directly).

The other program that helps in this process is the multipip program which anvil
is using to collapse a large set of requirement files into a single set of packages
and versions (which then goes into the finding/downloading/building functions). It
is likely useful also to determine pypi requirement incompatibilities (across git repos).

  $ ./tools/multipip -r glance/test-requirements.txt -r glance/requirements.txt -r nova/test-requirements.txt -r nova/requirements.txt
  Babel>=0.9.6
  Cheetah>=2.4.4
  PasteDeploy>=1.5.0
  SQLAlchemy>=0.7.8,<0.7.99
  WebOb==1.2.3
  amqplib>=0.6.1
  anyjson>=0.2.4
  argparse
  boto
  d2to1>=0.2.10,<0.3
  eventlet>=0.9.17
  greenlet>=0.3.1
  iso8601>=0.1.4
  kombu>=1.0.4
  lxml>=2.3
  netaddr>=0.7.6
  oslo.config>=1.2.0a3
  paramiko
  paste
  pbr>=0.5.16,<0.6
  pyasn1
  pyparsing>=1.5.7,<2.0
  python-cinderclient>=1.0.1
  python-glanceclient>=0.9.0
  python-keystoneclient>=0.2.0
  python-neutronclient>=2.2.3,<3.0.0
  routes>=1.12.3
  six
  sqlalchemy-migrate>=0.7.2
  stevedore>=0.10
  suds>=0.4
  websockify<0.4

Both programs (or derivations of) might be useful in the struggle against package
management systems that I think we all agree are not easy to always work with."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2013-08-03 20:19:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-03 21:07:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2013-08-05 05:55:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

I broadly agree with the general idea of using pypi v distro packages for simplicity.

As I mentioned in [1] I'm worried about what happens when these packages are bought in by other dependencies and then pip overwrites them (or they overwrite pip versions).  The idea proposed by Joshua Harlow of using distro packages or building packages on-the-fly is very interesting and worth investigation.  It would seem to solve the issue of pip overwriting system packages

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/39862/"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-08-05 06:38:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Feel free to try.

https://github.com/stackforge/anvil/tree/master/tools#py2rpm

Its part of the process anvil is using to do the pip->rpm conversion (and why anvil actually uses no pips in the end, all are either found from repos - and used if versions will match the needed requirements, or built on-the-fly). 

See this folder for the whole process.

https://github.com/stackforge/anvil/tree/master/anvil/packaging

 - base.py does all pip interactions
 - yum.py then interacts with the yum repos and other tools to then build 2 rpm repos (one for dependencies and one for openstack components)'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2013-08-05 12:21:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(5 inline comments)

apart from the recurring suggestion to add a comment in the filest, I couldn't upvote this change more :)"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-08-05 14:00:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

so, we've seriously been doing every effort to go in the other direction so that people can mostly get their distro versions, and only have to take the pip versions if their distro is out of date. If we are stripping out all of the packaging versions we might as well be running the gate on arch linux.

I think that if we are going down this path what we actually need is a tool that will act as a go between and install the package if sufficient to pip requirements, and not install it if it won't. Given that we're going to global requirements, sufficiency should be able to be figured out up front."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2013-08-05 15:16:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Something like yumfind that Josh mentions and/or building simple packages on the fly is something I'd be ok with - although I'm honestly not sure what the benefit is. We have a global requirements list. It is the source of record for what we do. We are not producing a linux distro. Whether our stuff works with the distro packages of the prior release of a linux distro is honestly not our job. Now - I _do_ think it's still important to test on ubuntu precise and not on arch or something, because there are many other things not encompased in our requirements list that affect things. But if we're talking about python libraries, then either we need to use pip to install the complete set (which is the current case) or we DON'T allow that, and we only allow being compatible with things already in distro so that we can be totally on packges. The second is completely un-viable.

I know we've been pushing more towards packages things, and I'm sorry for my continual part in that. I was wrong. It's mainly due to being a distro supporter for so long, and a person fan of packages. The thing is - we have to solve all of the engineering problems that exist in the world of not using packages, so having solved them, the only think packages for our python dependencies give us is more complexity."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-08-05 17:03:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I agree with the sentiment that its either all pips or all packages and not really anywhere in the middle. Its not really worth the pain to figure out the interactions between pip/python packaging and the distro packaging (apt/yum). But knowing from experience that both routes are painful, u just have to decide which one and stick with it I think in the end. Anvil was initially like devstack and tried to mix them, but that ended about 4 months ago when it was to much a PITA.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-08-06 17:57:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

I described the version conflict between python-boto required by euca2ools and openstack requirement in the comment on files/apts/general. revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-02 22:01:17.000000000', 'message': "Stop installing PyPI things via apt

It may, and in fact, it is, completely baffling to behold, but it turns
out that the interaction between distro installed and pip installed
libraries is not a good one. In fact, it's a completely and total
disaster which shows clearly the work of a bunch of provicial-minded
people who don't know how to cooperate or admit that someone else might
have a different opinion.

Nonetheless, thus is the world in which we actually exist, theory of how
things should be notwithstanding. We were requested by the distros to
stop managing our own apt repos, so we install our depends via pip now.
Additionally, we now actually even GATE on the pip requirements list.
That means that the requirements list that indicates packages from PyPI
is the absolute and total list of requirements in the form that we can
manage.

Thus - installing those packages also via apt is a not only a waste of
time, it's dangerous because of the undefined interactions between
distro and pip.

Change-Id: I18e480a3312078bde26fc590d4d793e0795e7078
"}, {'created': '2013-08-02 22:25:24.000000000', 'message': "Stop installing PyPI things via apt

That means that the requirements list that indicates packages from PyPI
is the absolute and total list of requirements in the form that we can
manage.

Thus - installing those packages also via apt is a not only a waste of
time, it's dangerous because of the undefined interactions between
distro and pip.

commit_message:
Stop installing PyPI things via apt

It may, and in fact, it is, completely baffling to behold, but it turns
out that the interaction between distro installed and pip installed
libraries is not a good one. In fact, it's a completely and total
disaster which shows clearly the work of a bunch of provicial-minded
people who don't know how to cooperate or admit that someone else might
have a different opinion.

Nonetheless, thus is the world in which we actually exist, theory of how
things should be notwithstanding. We were requested by the distros to
stop managing our own apt repos, so we install our depends via pip now.
Additionally, we now actually even GATE on the pip requirements list.
That means that the requirements list that indicates packages from PyPI
is the absolute and total list of requirements in the form that we can
manage.

Thus - installing those packages also via apt is a not only a waste of
time, it's dangerous because of the undefined interactions between
distro and pip.

Also, we an properly install the dev libs we need here, so that other
dev and test works right.

Closes-Bug: 1203723
Change-Id: I18e480a3312078bde26fc590d4d793e0795e7078

commit_message:
Handle the credentials as object

This refactorization makes simpler future credentials
 related changes.

- domains
- per process credential management

Change-Id: Ib032f582b1cb215672c593744e0fef81302e6d29

commit_message:
Remove ch_dochistory, use section_dochistory instead

Like in all other guides, let's place the history in the preface
and use section_dochistory instead of ch_dochistory.

Also, the config guide had a chapter called overview. Mark it as
preface like in all other guides.

Change-Id: I4de28356456286c7f3d7a340cf27f233d52cdfec

commit_message:
Replace using tests.utils part2

It is the second step to replace using tests.utils with
stack.common.test.
In this patch second part of tests is changed for using
openstack.common.test and added needed fixtures in test classes.

Change-Id: I81e3ff41827f7153b650255e219ce25cb282507b
bp: common-unit-tests

commit_message:
Catch the correct exception

ConfigParser.parse throws cfg.ParseError not the one in iniparser.
(note that cfg.py#L1231 has a reference to filename which is not
present in the initparser.ParseError)

Change-Id: I742ac254dbfb35d5a69b82b54a262d0341637f3d

[{'created': '2013-08-21 19:48:35.000000000', 'message': "Fix for consumer update for SQL backend

I noticed this while testing keystoneclient, the update for
consumer wasn't working because a new session was being
generated from _get_consumer.

commit_message:
Fix for consumer update for SQL backend

I noticed this while testing keystoneclient, the update for
consumer wasn't working because a new session was being
generated from _get_consumer.

fixes bug: #1215483

Change-Id: I0b6c96d403081368d3c227075333f7433ba35ee1

commit_message:
Fix Fibre Channel attach for single WWN

The code allowed for only a string of the WWN or a list of them.
Unfortunately unicode is also returned, for which the attach fails.
This patch allows for unicode as well.

Change-Id: I1d81abc3f8569ce8b3fb25c0e9c8aefd10e9aae8
Fixes: bug 1214413

subject: Move flake8 option from run_tests.sh to tox.ini
messages:
[{'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2013-08-19 23:16:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The changes to tox.ini make a rebase required.  I am also skeptical that E128 and E122 need to be added as something to skip as jenkins uses `tox -epep8` which already references the [flake8] section, and we are not skipping E128 when running in that mode."}, {'account_id': 7774, 'date': '2013-08-20 02:17:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I am no sure the meaning of "The changes to tox.ini make a rebase required". would you give me more explanation please ? 

I will abandon the changes of tox.ini, then the behavior of "run_tests.sh -p" and "tox -e pep8" will be same.'}, {'account_id': 7774, 'date': '2013-08-20 03:07:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

It is weird that the "run_tests.sh -p" and "tox -e pep8" get different result.
As you mentioned, jenkin use "tox -e pep8" to do the checking, it will get successful result. but run "run_tests.sh -p" will not pass through the checking, it will detect some E128 code.

After some investigation, I find that the flake8 version used by the above two commands are different.

$ ./tools/with_venv.sh  flake8 --version 
2.0 (pep8: 1.4.6, mccabe: 0.2.1, pyflakes: 0.7.3)

$ .tox/pep8/bin/flake8 --version 
2.0 (pep8: 1.4.5, mccabe: 0.2.1, pyflakes: 0.7.2, GitCheckCommitTitleBug: 0.0.1, GitCheckCommitTitleLength: 0.0.1, GitCheckCommitTitlePeriodEnding: 0.0.1, hacking.core: 0.0.1, ProxyChecker: 0.0.1)

since they use the same requirement file to install the python package, they should have same version. I will file a bug to trace it, and make some further investigation.

Anyway, let's first remove the flake8 option from run_tests.sh.'}, {'account_id': 7774, 'date': '2013-08-20 03:12:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-20 04:08:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Move flake8 option from run_tests.sh to tox.ini

flake8 will read the section [flake8] of tox.ini to guide the behavior.
In run_tests.sh, there is no need to add flake8 option in run_flake8()
function.

Bug #1214175

Change-Id: If3b84a0a3eecc1a9800fed6be9b24e648c161280

commit_message:
Enforce flavor access during instance boot

The code in the servers API did not pass the context when retrieving
flavor details.  That means it would use an admin context instead,
bypassing all flavor access control checks.

This patch includes the fix, and the corresponding unit test for the v2
API.

Closes-bug: #1212179

(cherry picked from commit 4054cc4a22a1fea997dec76afb5646fd6c6ea6b9)

Conflicts:
	nova/api/openstack/compute/plugins/v3/servers.py
	nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py
	nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/plugins/v3/test_servers.py
	nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/test_servers.py

Change-Id: I681ae9965e19767df22fa74c3315e4e03a459d3b

commit_message:
Sync py3kcompat from oslo

Python3 reorganized the standard library and moved several
functions to different modules and combined modules. Six
provides a consistent interface to the module through
six.moves

However urllib/urlparse is not covered by six.moves so
py3kcompat adds python2/python3 compatibility layer for
urllib/urlparse.

Change-Id: If1436d2260f1c8b6df8c514c8730e7bcf0e648b8
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:

'}, {'created': '2013-08-22 19:17:38.000000000', 'message': "Update from openstack/requirements

Pull in current requirments settings from
openstack/requirements.

This also requires that the test_image_utils test
is updated, it's currently raising and assertRaise
on a generic Exception which is now an H202 violation.

We'll pick one of the valid exceptions that can come

"}]
commit_message:
Update from openstack/requirements

Pull in current requirments settings from
openstack/requirements.

This also requires that the test_image_utils test
is updated, it's currently raising and assertRaise
on a generic Exception which is now an H202 violation.

We'll pick one of the valid exceptions that can come
from mkstemp and use it.

Change-Id: I170afd30f2348c8bb82c30b7f624f959da227731

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-16 12:24:45.000000000', 'message': "Protected matcher import

In python the names starts with '_'should not be used from another
package/distribution without a good reason.

The matchers are reachable from a not protected namespace.

Change-Id: I8892599edcbe7c4dd1cebea2c99e81a3221f8ef5
"}]
commit_message:
Protected matcher import

In python the names starts with '_'should not be used from another
package/distribution without a good reason.

The matchers are reachable from a not protected namespace.

Change-Id: I8892599edcbe7c4dd1cebea2c99e81a3221f8ef5
